content.text: \(\mathrm{n}(A \cap B)\),
\(\mathrm{n}(A \cup B)\)
Sets \(A\) and \(B\) are such that \(\mathrm{n}(A) = 15\) and \(\mathrm{n}(B) = 7\). Find the greatest and least possible values of
On a Venn diagram draw 3 sets \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\) such that
The function f is such that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 4x^{3} - 8x^{2} + ax + b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given
that \(2x - 1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) and that when \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) is divided by \(x + 2\) the remainder is 20. Find
remainder when \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) is divided by \(x - 1\)
Express the equation of the straight line graph in the form \(\lg N = m \lg t + \lg c\), where \(m\) and \(c\) are constants to be found
Hence express \(N\) in terms of \(t\)
Variables \(t\) and \(N\) are such that when \(\lg N\) is plotted against \(\lg t\), a straight line graph pass
through the points (0.45, 1.2) and (1, 3.4) is obtained
Find how many different six-digit numbers can be formed
Find how many of these six-digit numbers are
even,
greater than 500 000,
even and greater than 500 000
Six-digit numbers are to be formed using the digits 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9. Each digit may only be used once in any number
Find the velocity of the particle when \(t = 0\)
Find the value of \(t\) when the particle is first at rest
Find the distance travelled by the particle before it first comes to rest
Find the acceleration of the particle when \(t = \frac{3\pi}{4}\)
A particle moves in a straight line such that its displacement, \(x\) m, from a fixed point \(O\) at \(t\) s, is given by \(x = 3 + \sin 2t\), where \(t \geqslant 0\)
The diagram shows part of the graph \(y = p + 3\tan 3x\) passing through the points \((-\frac{\pi}{12}, - 5)\), \((0, p)\) and \((q, 1)\). Find the value of \(p\) and of \(q\)

It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = a \cos (bx) + c\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers. The maximum value of f is 11, the minimum value of f is 3 and the period of f is \(72^{\circ}\). Find the value of \(a\), of \(b\) and of \(c\)
Find the value of \(n\)
Using this value of \(n\), find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of
The coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(1 + \frac{x}{5}\right)^{n}\), where \(n\) is a positive integer, is \(\frac{3}{5}\)
Find \(\int (\mathrm{e}^{x} + 1)^{2} \mathrm{~d}x\) and hence evaluate \(\int_{0}^{2}(\mathrm{e}^{x} + 1)^{2} \mathrm{~d}x.\)
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = (4x + 1)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\). Given that the curve passes through the point with coordinates (2, 4.5), find the equation of the curve
Solve \(1 + \cot^{2}x = 8\sin x\) for \(0^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 360^{\circ}\)
Solve \(4 \sin(2y - 0.3) + 5 \cos(2y - 0.3) = 0\) for \(0 \leqslant y \leqslant \pi\) radians
By first expressing \(\theta\) in terms of \(r\), show that the perimeter, \(P\) cm, of the shaded region is given by \(P = 4r + \frac{8}{r}\)
Given that \(r\) can vary, show that the stationary value of \(P\) can be written in the form \(k\sqrt{2}\) , where \(k\) is a constant to be found
Determine the nature of this stationary value and find the value of \(\theta\) for which it occurs.

The figure shows a sector \(ABC\) of a circle centre \(C\), radius \(2r \mathrm{cm}\), where angle \(ACB\) is \(3\theta\) radians. The points \(D, E, F\) and \(G\) lie on an arc of a circle centre \(C\), radius \(r \mathrm{cm}\). The points \(D\) and \(G\) are the midpoints of \(CA\) and \(CB\) respectively. Angles \(DCE\) and \(FCG\) are each \(\theta\) radians. The area of the shaded region is \(5\mathrm{cm}^2\)
Write down, in terms of \(r\), the length of \(OC\)
Hence show that \(r = \frac{10 \sin \theta}{1 + \sin \theta}\)
Given that \(\theta\) can vary, find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}r}{\mathrm{d}\theta}\) when \(r = \frac{10}{3}\)
Given that \(r\) is increasing at \(2\mathrm{cm}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), find the rate at which \(\theta\) is increasing when \(\theta = \frac{\pi}{6}\)

The figure shows a sector \(OAB\) of a circle, centre \(O\), radius \(10\mathrm{cm}\). Angle \(AOB = 2\theta\) radians where \(0 < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\). A circle centre \(C\), radius \(r \mathrm{cm}\), touches the arc \(AB\) at the point \(D\). The lines \(OA\) and \(OB\) are tangents to the circle at the points \(E\) and \(F\) respectively
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives
